E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

MPLX is continually striving to make the Kenova LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, MPLX actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements. All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT) per Marathon policy. The Kenova Fire Department/Catlettsburg Refinery Fire and Rescue is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additionally, MPLX will work cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.

General Emergency Response

-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies; and
-Emergency drills with Terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.

Further, the Kenova LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, a Facility Response Plan (SMARTPLAN) is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with Kenova Fire Department/Catlettsburg Refinery Fire and Rescue.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Kenova LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal keeps records for all incidental and significant chemical releases inclusive of any root cause analyses and associated, follow-up actions. This is a new butane batch blending process; consequently, there have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Kenova Fire Department/Catlettsburg Refinery Fire and Rescue along with Cabell/Wayne County LEPC. A Facility Response Plan (SMARTPLAN) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

In the event of an emergency involving the Kenova LP Terminal butane tank blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Kenova Fire Department/Catlettsburg Refinery Fire and Rescue and request their assistance. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Kenova LP Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Butane Batch Blending Process.

Butane Batch Blending is a batch type process based on seasonal RVP adjustments. Butane is received by truck (transports), stored on-site, and piped directly to injection points feeding the dock and off-site locations. Process safety controls include Smart-hoses, low emission couplers, emergency shutoff valves throughout (manual, automated and thermally actuated), vessel PRVs, excess flow valves, hydrostatic pressure relief, and process area hydrocarbon detectors along with on-site fire water monitors. Access to the Kenova LP Terminal and butane offload/storage area is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

The Kenova LP Terminal accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning/response programs help Marathon effectively manage the hazards posed by the regulated substances to the Terminal employees, surrounding public, and environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

The MPLX-Kenova LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Kenova LP Terminal is an on-shore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Kenova, WV. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low sulfur diesel/#2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.

Kenova LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. MPLX promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals
D. An overview of the emergency response program
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety
